Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding and Analyzing User-Prosthesis Interaction for Designing a Volitional Controller for Powered Lower Limb Prostheses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although volitional control of prosthetic arms has been studied intensively in recent years, similar technology has not yet been developed for lower limb prostheses, due in part to the lack of control capability in current passive prosthetic legs. Two emerging technologies, powered lower limb prostheses and neural-machine interfaces (NMI), have opened up new possibilities for allowing leg amputees to operate prostheses intuitively and to perform various activities in a natural way. It remains, however, to demonstrate the feasibility of volitional control for powered prosthetic legs. This is the PI's goal in the current project: to develop and implement a novel volitional controller that allows users with transfemoral amputations to operate a multifunctional, powered prosthetic leg intuitively and safely. To this end, she will systematically investigate and quantify the interaction effects between lower limb amputees and powered artificial legs. Intrinsic control (i.e., control based on intrinsic mechanical feedback) for a prototype powered transfemoral (TF) prosthesis will be developed with finite-state machine and impedance control mechanisms so that it can assist amputees in performing various activities in weight bearing and non-weight bearing situations. The design of the volitional control will be based on a multi-model engineering framework that integrates intent decoders with intrinsic prosthesis control so as to create feed-forward control in a powered TF prosthesis while ensuring amputee safety. Finally, a proof-of-concept prototype of a volitionally-controlled, powered TF prosthesis will be implemented and evaluated in real time on patients with TF amputations.

Broader Impacts: Project outcomes will significantly advance lower limb prostheses technology, which will in turn lead to quality of life improvements for the large and growing population of lower limb amputees. Similar technology should be applicable to control of powered orthotics, which would benefit patient populations with neuromotor deficits. The experimental data collected in the project will shed light on human motor control mechanisms, which should benefit diverse fields such as kinesiology and neuroscience. The new technologies developed in this research (including sensors, communication, algorithms, control, etc.) should help advance research across human-centered computing (including, for example, exoskeleton control and wearable sensors for health monitoring). Through integration of her research into comprehensive education and outreach programs, the PI will help educate the next generation of engineers and scientists, who will impact the future of science and technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This career award supported our considerable contributions to both research and education. The goal of our research contributions were and continue to be toward improving the quality of life of people with disabilities, primarily limb loss. Through this work, we trained students joining the next-generation of engineers and scientists, as well as led interactive activities for pre-college students, in hopes of inspiring them to pursue higher education and careers in STEM disciplines. Through both avenues of my career development, we were able to build a synergistic community of students, clinicians, researchers, and amputees that all play critical roles in advancing assistive technology and the state of rehabilitation.

 

Lower limb loss is one of the major causes of disability in the US and causes a significant decline in amputees’ independence, balance, confidence, social engagement, and ability to perform basic daily activities. At the start of this award, modern powered knee prostheses had been developed to provide power and more function for transfemoral amputees, but the prosthesis behavior was dominated by automation, rather than the amputee user’s intent. My team developed a new volitional, neural-controlled powered prosthesis controller that allows amputees to walk safely and effectively on various terrains based on their intent. In order to ensure amputee users’ safety, we extensively and systematically studied the effects of errors and delays of a neural-machine interface (used for user intent recognition) on the stability and balance of amputee users. We learned that critical decoding errors that may lead users to stumble or fall were linked to specific phases of gait, duration of the error, and powered knee changes in mechanical work. Through systematic testing with multiple amputees, we constructed a response manifold to map the user’s full-body angular momentum and the prosthesis errors of varying amplitude and timing. We also developed a fault-tolerant control strategy to detect and counteract the disturbances caused by neural-decoding errors in the prosthesis. The outcomes of these studies provide a promising engineering solution to make the neural control of powered prostheses safe and reduce amputees’ risk of falls.

 

We also expanded our approach to ensuring amputee users’ safety by involving another very important factor - the environment in which amputees interact. We developed an environment-aware neural-machine interface that improved the accuracy of predicting the user’s locomotion mode, and we analyzed both intrinsic (i.e. gait kinematics and kinetics) and extrinsic (e.g. obstacle material properties and location) factors that can lead to trips and developed a trip-prediction algorithm. The capacity for assistive devices to prevent and mitigate trips (a major cause of unintentional falls) is critical to prevent fall-related injuries.

 

Environmental factors not only include changing terrains, but also situations such as carrying loads (e.g. backpacks, groceries). To determine whether or not prosthesis controllers should also be adaptive when amputee users carry load, we studied the effect of powered knee control parameters on the gait performance of amputee users walking with load. We learned that load-specific control parameters can be beneficial (and subjectively preferred) for amputees carrying load in their daily life. We also preliminarily developed a user-centered design evaluation process for sit-to-stand action that modeled users’ objective and subjective data on a design space. By investigating the interaction between the amputee user, prosthesis, and environment, these projects more broadly contributed to the enhancement of transfemoral amputees’ physical and social engagement in their community.

 

In order to broaden the impact of our research, we discussed the outcomes of this project with companies that specialize in prosthetic technology, with the potential for future collaboration and commercialization of this novel work. In addition, we disseminated our research through well-known academic journals and conferences, as well as local media, invited talks, and events such as a Science Cafe for the local, general public. Through the sharing of our research with broader audiences, we were able to connect with and learn from our community and those with unique perspectives.

 

Furthermore, we actively engaged students of all ages in our work, especially females, an underrepresented group in STEM. For example, we trained more than 20 (6 female) graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students in biomedical engineering, electrical/computer engineering, and mechanical engineering. Every year, we participated in at least 3 major educational and outreach activities for 30-250 middle and/or high school students, depending on the activity. An unexpected result of both our research and education efforts was the culmination of a collaborative community of students, teachers, faculty, clinicians, and people with disability, all essential to advancing the state of prosthetics and rehabilitation.
